thread.title: San Antonio Spurs coach Gregg Popovich named head coach of USA Basketball Men's National Team

author: Jeff McDonald
title: San Antonio Spurs coach Gregg Popovich named head coach of USA Basketball Men's National Team
text:

3. He was born Jan. 28, 1949 in the Indiana Harbor section of East Chicago, Indiana to a Serbian father, Raymond and Croatian mother, Katherine.

... more Image 5 of 42 4. His first childhood dream was to play for legendary coach Johnny Baratto at Washington High in East Chicago, where his father was a star in the 1930s.

4. His first childhood dream was to play for legendary coach Johnny Baratto at Washington High in East Chicago, where his father was a star in the 1930s.

... more Image 6 of 42 5. When Popovich accepted his commission to the Air Force in 1966 after his high school graduation, he became one of the first seniors in Merrillville history to attend a military academy.

5. When Popovich accepted his commission to the Air Force in 1966 after his high school graduation, he became one of the first seniors in Merrillville history to attend a military academy.
Read more:
... more Image 7 of 42 6. Before the world knew him as “Pop,” Merrillville peers called him “C.C.” since his high school basketball coach mistakenly and repeatedly referred to Popovich as “Craig” instead of Gregg. Teammates paired the misnomer with his middle name, “Charles,” to create the new nickname.
Read more: Popovich's steel roots built solid foundation for NBA success
6. Before the world knew him as “Pop,” Merrillville peers called him “C.C.” since his high school basketball coach mistakenly and repeatedly referred to Popovich as “Craig” instead of Gregg.
... more Image 8 of 42 7. Popovich was once cut from his high school basketball team during his sophomore year. He spent the summer after practicing relentlessly, it is during this trying time friends believed he learned “to be tough.” He returned to the team his junior year as the starting center, but still “Craig” to his coach.
Read more: Popovich's steel roots built solid foundation for NBA success
7. Popovich was once cut from his high school basketball team during his sophomore year. He spent the summer after practicing relentlessly, it is during this trying time friends believed he learned “to be

8. Popovich also played baseball in high school.
Read more: Popovich's steel roots built solid foundation for NBA success Photo: San Antonio Express-News Image 10 of 42 9. When he was off the hardwood, he spent his teenage years with friends cruising, eating 14-cent hamburgers at the town’s burger joint called The Mug, watching drive-in movies, listening to Motown tunes, dancing (yes, dancing) and road-tripping to Wrigley Field to catch Cubs games.
Read more: Popovich's steel roots built solid foundation for NBA success

In 2005, shortly after coaching the Spurs to their third championship, Popovich returned to the Merrillville gym where the school retired his No. 21 high school jersey. To the delight of the crowd, Popovich wore his 1966 letterman jacket to the event.

17. His first assignment after graduation was with the 6594th Support Group in Sunnyvale, California, in the Silicon Valley. The group was part of the top-secret Air Forces Satellite Control Facility, under the command of Space and Missile Systems Organization (SAMSO.)

Popovich’s goals span further than the game of basketball. “My goal is to drink as much of it as I can before I die so my kids don’t use 7-UP and make sangria out of the wine. That’s my goal,” the championship-winning connoisseur told ESPN’S Chris Perkins.

The Spurs won 111-107. (Photo by Stephen Dunn/Getty Images) LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 28: Head coach Gregg Popovich and Kawhi Leonard #2 of the San Antonio Spurs confer as they play the Los Angeles Clippers during Game Five of the Western Conference quarterfinals of the ... more Image 27 of 42 Spurs coach Gregg Popovich's first head coaching job was at Pomona-Pitzer in Claremont, California. He coached there from 1979-86 and in 1987-88 after taking a leave of absence to be on Larry Brown's staff at Kansas for a season. Popovich was 76-127 in those eight seasons guiding the Sagehens to their first SCIAC title in 68 years after the 1985-86 season. Photo: Express-News-file Photo Image 42 of 42 San Antonio Spurs coach Gregg Popovich named head coach of USA Basketball Men's National Team 1 / 42 Back to Gallery Add another job title to Gregg Popovich's already impressive coaching resume — Team USA Coach.
The Spurs' Popovich has been named the country's national coach for 2017-2020, USA Basketball announced Friday.
RELATED: Jeff McDonald on the Spurs preseason, Coach Pop and Team USA.
Popovich, 66, will replace Mike Krzyzewski following the 2016 Olympics in Rio De Janeiro. Krzyzewski is moving to an advisory role alongside Team USA managing director Jerry Colangelo.
Popovich is set to coach the men's squad for the 2019 FIBA World Cup in China and the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.
In a release from USA Basketball, Popovich — a 1970 graduate of the U.S. Air Force Academy — said he was "humbled and honored" to be tabbed for the job.
"I will do my utmost to maintain the high standards of success, class and character established by Jerry, Coach K and the many players who have sacrificed their time on behalf of USA Basketball," said Popovich, who served Team USA as an assistant under Larry Brown in the 2004 Athens Olympics.
In Friday's release, Colangelo said he is pleased to transition the program from "one of the game's greatest coaches in Mike Krzyzewski to another of basketball's greatest coaches in Gregg Popovich."
"This progression plan will also help ensure that our National Team will continue to build on the culture and success we have achieved since launching the program," Colangelo said.
The Express-News will have more on this story as it develops.
